Before suffering from "Superbabies 2" I was lucky to survive while watching "The Return of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1994)". Check it out if you think that you're strong enough. I rated it 1/10, but I had no idea that "Superbabies 2" exist. If I based all the ratings on 1/10 for "Superbabies 2", 99% of all the leftover movies would've had 9/10 or 10/10. I was ready for a challenge when I saw this movie ranked #1 on the "Bottom 100" list. Well, I thought I was ready.I don't want to talk about acting, scenario, etc. because a lot of reviewers already did it. I would like to sign under every word. But I have a couple of remarks that I would like to point out.1. The Kahuna's friend Zack. The story tells Kahuna found him in Russia. Wow. I live in Moscow and I bet that there is not a single person who's name is Zack! 2. I watched this "movie" with my girlfriend. It was so boring that after a half an hour she began to scream at me, because she wanted to stop it.. She even offered that we play "Saints Row" instead! Somehow it made her so angry that she went to the other room and didn't talk to me until the next day. Just a possibility of breaking with your girlfriend because of "Superbabies 2" plain and simple stinks. It's insane.

I can't stand this movie. I remember being younger and wanting to see it. My spazzy little brain told me "Oh, go see this movie! You'll love it!" You lied, brain. This is the "Jaws: The Revenge" of comedies! If I get the chance, I will go to the director's home, hit him in the crotch with a rattle, and destroy EVERYTHING HE LOVES! This movie is so bad, Uwe Boll looks down on it! This makes me yearn for the Super Mario Bros. movie! I watched the movie over and over, hoping to find a hidden joke. Looks like I did. "Viewers are morons and will watch anything with 'cute' babies." Why the quotes around cute? They aren't cute! They're annoying! They're the little brothers and sisters of the universe! I want to tear my eyes out after watching it!

reviews.review_title: Sad Way for Clark to End His Career
reviews.content: Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2 (2004) 1/2 (out of 4) This sequel to the 1999 hit was sadly the last feature directed by Bob Clark, which is a real shame. This film has an evil TV mogul (Jon Voight) trying to understand and breakdown baby talk but his evil goons have a major problem with a Rambo type baby. Yeah, that's the plot or something like it. The first BABY GENIUSES movie was pretty bad but I gave the filmmakers credit for at least trying to do something original even if the story itself was a bit too creepy to actually work. This film here is just a really bad rehash of a bad story that didn't work in the first place so there wasn't anywhere to go but down and this thing here really crashes. I'm really not sure what the filmmakers were going for but you'd think their target audience would be children yet every bit of the story here would be way too confusing and boring for kids. Even worse is that the baby stuff is so uneven with everything else in the film that it would be impossible for the adults to get anything out of it either. I'm really not sure why they'd want to alienate children and especially since they're the ones this was made for. The story makes very little sense but I guess this here is to be expected. The performances really aren't much better with Voight and Scott Baio isn't much better. SUPERBABIES: BABY GENIUSES 2 is a very bad movie but with that said I don't think I'd call it one of the worst ever, which is where it's reputation is at. No, the film still looked professionally made but that's about all it had going for it.

I would give this movie 0 stars, but unknown (yet) actor Mart Bart from Lithuania really shines in it. Although he wasnt the main character in his few scenes he delivers. And he delivers quite a lot: from laughter to tears, from joy to anger. I think he will have a great career. Mark my words: there will be a new star in Hollywood.

SuperBabies: Baby Geniuses 2 is the follow-up to 1999's Baby Geniuses. In it, four smart babies team up with 7-year-old "defender of children everywhere" Kahuna to prevent media mogul Bill Biscane's plot to enslave the world through powerful subliminal TV programming.Babies start jumping at day-care center Bobbins World, in the stewardship of Stan and Jean Bobbins. (Stan's brother from the first film owns the center but is busy saving children overseas.) The Bobbins are preparing for the arrival of Mr. Biscane, who, at this point in the film, is an internationally recognized advocate of children and orphans. Biscane has chosen the Bobbins' upscale L.A. day care to premier his new television show for kids. Stan hopes the exposure will turn the day care into a nationally known brand, "the McDonald's of day care." Biscane has other ideas.As the Bobbinses work themselves into a high-stress lather over the near visit, four smart babies:Archie, Finkleman, Rosita and Alex sit talking to one another in a play area. To the ordinary watcher, it looks as if they're just talking baby talk. But Jean becomes convinced that they're actually having a conversation. And she's right: Archie is telling the other toddlers about the legend of Kahuna, a 7-year-old überspy who prevented the evil Nazi-like commander Kane's plot to enslave orphaned East German children.The other babies dismiss Archie's tall tale. But they soon discover that Kahuna is no legend when he comes to their rescue—which they desperately need after getting unwittingly dragged into Biscane's malevolent sights—tricked out with all the requisite Bond-like hardware, including a snazzy rocket-powered three-wheeler. Along the way, Kahuna empowers the babies to believe in themselves, revealing each one's superpower!.This movie is so great .I still do not know why it is heavily underrated. It was an enjoyable thing to do watching the movie on DVD and I am so certain it would be magical to see this excellent movie in 3D at the movies.

Jon Voight's performance in this film was downright spellbinding. He brought what we in the industry call pizazz from the opening scene in this below average movie. His fights scene were a personal highlight of the movie for myself, however it must be said that when he originally fought Kahuna (superbaby) it was the latter that really shone through, and produced an Oscar/Emmy winning performance. Kahuna, despite obviously being a child, somehow managed to look like a midget stuntman throughout his fight scenes, which was a classy and well thought out touch. It must be mentioned that we appreciated, on a professional level, the Three Stooges reference and were pretty much blown away by the obscure Popeye reference to Popeye. Still on Kahuna, his superpowers were up there with other really good superheroes like Batman and/or Iron Man. His superpowers were as follows: fighting, glowing green, driving a small little persons car, pilot, floating on a bean bag, meditating and being about 5 or 6 forever. Oh and his dashing good looks and nursery charms. Do you know fans what was out of this world, and maybe any other world? The CGI and special effects thereof in this film. Amazingly the production team managed to make it look like the babies were actually saying these really funny one liners like "Can a brother get some water?" (We get that satire) As huge fans of computers, we really enjoyed the babies frequent use of the MSN Kids operating system, and would like to petition for its return to all new computers from this point onwards. Loved the cameo of the Whoopster Whoopi Goldberg. It was like she wasn't there and was actually at home the whole time, but we obviously know she wasn't. Ha. However, it must be said that the blistering appearance of the Grammy winning superstar making Florida band O-Town was something to behold for generations past and present. Those guys brought it, and we loved it. Loved it. In conclusion, this film was below average. That guy from Diagnosis Murder wasn't very good. The plot was a bit weird. The pacing was off, and almost strange. So, we have had to dock several points accordingly. As a result, we have been forced to give it a 9.0 out of 10.0. Two thumbs up. Would definitely watch it again, without such high expectations. GOLD. Better than Battle Royale.

reviews.review_title: A Brilliant Kaufman style look into the psychology of American youth.
reviews.content: This movie is everything wrong with America. but there is something brilliant about that. it fails on every single level, effects, acting, score, editing, direction, lighting, background, and sets. But if you look at it, this film was obviously made by adults, to sell this as a summer forgettable to young young YOUNG children. but it becomes more than that. its a movie that shows how we can deceive the youth into taking whatever garbage we shovel them (a very obvious hint to religion and how we have destroyed our natural resources leaving the next generation hopeless.)its a movie that teaches us that the American public can forgive racial stereotyping if everything else around it is that terrible. it really shows how mediocre we are as a society. although i liked dissecting this movie to its core, its still quite possibly the worst movie ever made and sitting through it will scar you as much as a 90 hour rerun of two girls one cup. but other than that. check it out. illegally download it. don't support the film makers. but do check it out.

Many people only see the surface of this movie. They see the funny jokes and the excellent action scenes and well thought out plot, but there is so much more to this movie. Our hero, Kahuna, is eventually revealed to be the brother of the villain, Kane. This is truly symbolic of the close bond between the light and the dark, good and evil. It also humanizes each of the characters and shows how easily they could have turned out differently. The story of how Kahuna got his powers is also an intricately beautiful tale. Kane was trying to get the superpowers for himself but the vial containing the experimental liquid fell out of his hands and instead Kahuna drank some of it. In his attempt to become powerful, fate decided that Kane was not fit for the great responsibility and instead bequeathed it to Kahuna. Was fate wrong? What if Kane had the powers? He would never have been so bitter about Kahuna being special instead of him. He would never have taken all those children and been a Nazi. Kahuna would have been normal, but did he ever want anything else? Kahuna never asked for the powers, they were given to him. Maybe if only fate had allowed Kane to become super instead of Kahuna then none of this would have happened. Fate and Destiny are omnipotent and yet they often make mistakes. Thats what this movie is really trying to teach us.

The movie is also great quality springing from best direction----to best cinematography. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves great movies...It's a masterpiece to say the least...All I can say is....Give Scott Baio the Oscar*.....NOW! I loved every minute of this joyful, yet tear jerking event....John Voight hits all the right notes! Masterpiece....I bow down to the worlds greatest movie ever!

Never before has a film touched on such delicate issues as coming of age and the loss of innocence as expertly as this. It follows the story of main character, baby Christopher, as he crawls away from home, driven out by his alcoholic and abusive twin sister Jennie and takes up a life of organized crime. That's right, this film can be compared to 'The Godfather', and if I am to do so, I must say that it is indeed precisely 3146 times better.A film like this only comes around once in a life time. This is our Charlie Chaplin. The Magnum Opus of this generation. At the risk of starting a religious war, the director of this film, Bob Clark, should not only be appointed as pope, but also receive the title of God, 3 Nobel peace prizes, and also a butler space monkey. He makes Jesus look like Hitler.That is really all that needs to be said. In conclusion, Jesus is worse than Hitler.

reviews.review_title: Vintage Bob Clark ------ Bob brings out the best in adventure for youngsters with this one -- he saved it for the end!
reviews.content: I viewed this film on television, a French language version, over the Christmas(2007)Holidays while visiting in Alma Quebec, Canada (region of Lac St-Jean). I missed the opening credits and had no idea who had directed this 'delightful' work. Before long I was guessing this wee treat to be the work of Bob Clark, and am now delighted to learn that he is indeed the director. Few of those watching with me spoke English, and even though this film is very "American" in every aspect, everything seemed to work for this audience, who truly enjoyed all that was offered. Bob's work, in my opinion, from Black Christmas to the present had occasionally been 'uneven'(although come to think of it, what director has not, at times, been 'uneven' over a career) I think A Christmas Story is his best work, a film I enjoyed immensely. However, Super Babies is a darn fine match and Bob is able to capture the essentials required in childhood adventure - something in it for kids of all ages. I'll miss him, and I will never forget the "little boy" in him. DMR

Don't let me get started on the visual effects as not eve Avatar can top this masterpiece, this film looks so good I'm am appalled that it is not even out on Blu-ray! Overall this film is for everyone, the jokes are hilarious, the action scenes are nail-biting and the polish of this family adventure is perfectly executed. Superbabies is a beautiful blend of action and comedy. The fact that the heroes are babies only adds to the movies pure brilliance. The story is quite unique and is something you wouldn't expect in a kid-friendly comedy like this. It has many twists and turns for a mature adult to enjoy, and enough Morgan Freeman so the kids can follow along. The jokes consist of funny references the adults will love, with some potty jokes thrown in (not enough to disgust the adults though) so the kids can have a laugh too. Each of the characters are likable and have unique personalities. Each of the characters has a deep backstory that is gone into at certain points in the film. The film gives enough attention to each of the characters and I found myself looking forward to when each of the characters would get a moment of focus. To make a long review short; Superbabies is an amazing film that will easily be your kid's favorite film, and is also a film you'll find yourself enjoying a lot.

I came into this knowing it had been touted as the worst movie of all time (see IMDB's Bottom 100 list), but as I committed to watching it with a bunch of friends while indulging in a few beverages, the main question I had was "Will it at least be ENJOYABLY bad?". And although it isn't a masterpiece of awesomely awful film like THE ROOM is, I can honestly answer "yes". Just don't consider watching it alone and sober. The effects are terrible (and strangely disturbing in parts), the plot jumps all over the place while making very little sense, the dialogue is as bad as you'd expect, and most importantly Jon Voight gives one of the most bizarrely over-the-top performances ever. But I had a wonderful time laughing AT the film. The only genuinely positive thing I could say is that there were 1 or 2 moments that I thought maybe the laughs were intended by the film-makers, but they were few and far between. My suggestion? Get your mates, get some drinks, and have a Superbabies Drinking Game Night. Just drink whenever the character, Kahuna, is mentioned by name (it's a lot!).

I can never look at "A Christmas Story" in the same way again, thanks to this goddamned movie. What can even be said about it, other than it has a couple of ideas in it which could have been, under very, VERY different circumstances, used in an interesting way? Jon Voight further proves that he should give up his Oscar (he puts on a completely fake German accent, and generally goes through the motions, which are humiliating ones), while the rest of the cast prove they should never get work again. Whoopi Goldberg makes a cameo--whether it's more embarrassing than her being in THEODORE REX or not would require me to see that film, and that's not bloody likely. The special effects are appallingly crude; the babies' lips, while digitally manipulated, still don't remotely sync up with the dialogue, but the dialogue is terrible anyway, so it's no great loss. Gregory Poppen's script is rambling and incoherent, and Bob Clark's (director of the aforementioned "A Christmas Story") direction is anonymous and spiritless. The child actors seem hardly to have been aware they were in a film at all, which is just as well; Skyler Shaye and Justin Chatwin play a teen couple, who are so dull as to have nothing worth saying about them. Deren Abram's production design fails by giving the Kahuna (the "hero") a secret lair which appears completely uncongenial to habitation, especially for children; it's a combination of THE NEVER-ENDING STORY and WILLY WONKA, but without charm or imagination. A spark of interest is raised when it is shown that the Kahuna pets and companions are almost all holograms; the loneliness of this situation could have been profitably used in a better film. But this is not that film, it is a dull, incoherent, crass, and intellectually offensive one. It's scarcely worth watching even for bad-movie lovers.

there are many words i could use to describe this movie. there are many words i could use to describe my feelings after watching this movie. i am trying not to use foul language, but i might have to later on in this review, as i really have an intense hatred for this movie. all i can really say is that if you have ever heard of this movie, you have probably heard how god-awful it is. god-awful would be an eternal improvement though. bob clark was the director of this movie. he was known for his raunchy 80's comedies porky's and its sequel. those were the two of the earliest college comedies to ever be recognized. they were hilarious and spawned many clones. and then after a whole handful of other movies no one has ever heard of, out comes baby geniuses, which was an absolutely terrible movie that garnered some really bad reviews. i was not impressed in the least. then bob clark's last film comes out. this was his LAST film. what a way to go, mr. clark. from pioneering the world of comedy to pioneering the world of s**t. there, i swore. again, with this film, they have talented stars in it, well actually just jon voight. all the rest suck already. this movie is an abomination to the film industry. this makes me say something that i might not say on any other film. this was equally as bad as manos: the hands of fate. there are absolutely no redeeming qualities about this. nothing can explain the inherent torture i went through subjecting myself to this. at one point, i had to pause this and walk around outside for some fresh air after almost getting sick at the waste of comedy. the same jokes were used in this movie as was in the original. why would anyone let them make a sequel??? let alone make a SECOND SEQUEL???? yeah, there's another one of these slated for release soon. its like the people behind date movie, epic movie, and disaster movie. DO YOU NOT REALIZE THAT YOU ARE FAILING MISERABLY AT WHAT YOU DO???!!!!! watching this movie might make you think of a question to ask me. why would i watch this? why would i subject myself to pain and torture? because i am a movie critic and it is my job to warn you of how entirely detestable, abhorrent, heinous, and ungodly these kinds of movies are. i had to look up synonyms for bad things to describe my feelings. never watch this, please.

In the beginning, it all just seemed like some beautiful, horrible dream...
 
It was nearly two years ago now that I first heard of the film that would become [i]Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2[/i].  You see, Access Hollywood was on right before Survivor (and still probably is, though I've mostly given up on Survivor since it started sucking so royally) and I'd gotten into the habit of watching it so my blood could get good and angried.  "THAT'S NOT FRIGGING NEWS," I'd scream at Pat O'Brien, deaf to my pleading to stop, "YOU SHOULD ALL BE SHOT AND KILLED!"
 
But it was Access Hollywood that first brought me into the world of [i]Superbabies[/i].  They did a behind-the-scenes report on it, and interviewed star Scott Baio.  The next morning, I had to convince myself that it wasn't a dream.  Nobody would believe me that such a film could possibly exist.  "Yeah, it's a sequel to [i]Baby Geniuses[/i], but this time the babies are superheroes, and Scott Baio's in it!"  
 
Just look at that last sentence.  It's crazy talk.  I'm amazed I wasn't locked up.
 
Then, a good deal of time later, ads for Superbabies: Baby Geniuses 2 started appearing on billboards and on the sides of buses.  This was no dream.  This was real.  And it was coming to theaters no less, not dumped to video inconspicuously where nobody would notice a desperate Oscar-winning actor (Jon Voight), a one-time next-big-thing (Vanessa Angel) and TV's "Chachie" cavorting with infants made to look like they have superpowers thanks to bad CGI.  
 
How could such a thing be?  How could such a cinematic monster possibly exist, much less be foisted upon hundreds of thousands of unsuspecting moviegoers?
 
Two words: David Paul.
 
These two words may not mean anything to you, nor should they.  But David Paul is the producer of [i]Superbabies[/i].  He's also the producer of the original [i]Baby Geniuses[/i], Anthony Michael Hall's directorial debut[i] Hail Caesar[/i], the Paul Rodriguez vehicle [i]A Million to Juan[/i], and his own ego projects, including the intolerable [i]Slapstick of Another Kind[/i] (Jerry Lewis does sci-fi!) and the even more intolerable[i] Eternity[/i] (Jon Voight does... er, eternity!).  He got his "start" (after producing [i]Falling in Love Again[/i]) at 17 directing [i]Slapstick[/i], a film financed by his family.
 
In other words, David Paul comes from a very, very rich family that can afford to make horrible, horrible movies that nobody would ever, ever want to see and have them get released.  
 
In fact, he'd make a much better super-villain than Jon Voight in [i]Superbabies[/i], an incompetent German intent on taking over the world (probably) using hidden signals in an idiotic kid's TV program hosted by a poorly-made-up toad that he plans to introduce by showing it in the middle of a park, sponsored by a tiny day care center, run by Baio and Angel.  All of this is just plan nonsensical and stupid, and I haven't even mentioned the damn Superbabies yet.
 
See, Voight's brother is a kid named Kahuna, who took some secret formula designed by their father and now doesn't age (he's actually in his 70's, thought he looks 8) and has super powers, a secret chamber and lots of gadgets that do things that don't make a damn bit of sense.
 
Yes, Kahuna.  I don't know why either.  I guess kids today love references to surf movies of the '60s.
 
So the toddler son of Baio and Angel, along with three other kids at the day care that don't seem to have parents, teams up with Kahuna, who, thanks to his weird science gizmos, manages to give them superpowers.  There's Captain Courage, who is strong, Miss Cupid, who causes men to turn gay, Bouncing Boy, who makes DC Comics sue the filmmakers, and Brain Boy, who has the amazing ability to stand around and let other people kick bad guys in the crotch.
 
While the talking babies aren't as horrifyingly creepy as that of the first film (and nowhere near the nightmare-inducing blasphemy-against-all-that-is-right that was the dancing baby of "Ally McBeal"), there's still no effort to make the kids look like they're even coming close the emotions expressed in their dialogue.  The "gags" basically consist of babies saying catch-phrases (only with the word "diaper" in there somewhere), though it's to the filmmaker's credit that there aren't that many poop and fart jokes.
 
Of course, when that filmmaker is Bob Clark, the once-respected man behind [i]A Christmas Story, Black Christmas, Murder by Decree[/i] and [i]Deathdream[/i]... ugh.
 
Just, ugh, Bob.  Ugh.  Still, I know you need a check.
 
To their credit, Baio and Angel only embarass themselves during the opening scene when they're forced to spew some awful expository dialogue.  They leave that up to Voight, who forces out a performance that makes his role in [i]Anaconda[/i] look restrained.  The kids... well, none of the kids will probably ever be seen again.  I mean, have you seen Jonathan Lipnicki lately?  What the hell is up with [i]him[/i]?
 
Sorry, getting distracted.  Watching [i]Superbabies[/i] has caused my brain to melt.  Needless to say, unless you're under 9 (in I.Q. points, not age) or an undiscriminating pedophile, there's no reason ever to expose yourself to this.  I knew about it, and that should have been enough for me, but noooooooo, I had to go prove that I could handle it.  
 
I am [i]such[/i] an idiot.
Never see this movie at all!

[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Archie: Hes Captain Courageous and is played by Michael and Max Iles.[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Finkleman: Hes Brain Boy and is played by Jordan and Jared Scheideman.[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Alex: Hes the Bounce Baby and is played by Joshua and Maxwell Lockheart[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Rosita: Shes the Cupid Girl and is played by Keana and Maia Bastidas[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Bill Biscane: Hes the head of a powerful media company and is played by Jon Voight.[/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000][u]Plot Summary[/u][/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]The story starts off with Archie, Finkleman, Alex and Rosita talking about a hero named Kahuna and how he saved babies from the German camps. [/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Bill Biscane shows up and launches a new television channel for kids that will sweep the world. But theres a hitch in his plan  his henchmen lose a critical DVD to the babies (Archie Finkleman, Alex and Rosita). But the babies are saved from capture by Kahuna. Kahuna takes them to his hideout and shows them about.[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Thats where they discover a chamber that lets them become superheroes. They step into the chamber and think about what sort of superheroes they could become.[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]And then theres some side story about a guy and a girl who might be in love, then Kahuna gets captured.[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Then theres a part where the other four babies get a recorded message from Kahuna that they the fate of all kids rests on their small shoulders and they should become the superheroes they imagined while in that chamber they discovered. If they do, then theres a chance that they can stop Biscanes evil plan.[/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]SCORING
[u]Main[/u][u] Male Characters[/u][/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Babies are cute to look at and listen to with their strange language, but theyre not cute to look at when theyre kicking bad guy butt or talking like adults. Its hard to believe theyre that smart.[/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Bill Biscane is just your average bad guy out to rule the world. SCORE: [b]2[/b][/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000][u]Supporting Cast[/u][/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]There are other adults in this film, but darn it, I cant remember a thing about them. SCORE: [b]3[/b].[/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000][u]Plot[/u][/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Reality check guys. How can someone brain wash everyone with television? How can a chamber turn babies into superheroes? How can any adult want to act in a movie where they get beaten up by babies? Its just terrible. SCORE: [b]1.[/b][/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000][u]Originality[/u][/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]This is your standard superhero movie where the good guys are out to save the day  if they were wearing diapers. SCORE: [b]3[/b].[/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000][u]Violence Factor[/u][/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Theres a double standard here: Babies beat up on adults throughout the film without any fear of retaliation  because if any adult hits any baby, its child abuse and the producers of the film would get crucified by the parents and by the general public. SCORE: [b]2.[/b][/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000][u]Other Moral Issues[/u][/color][/font][/size]
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000]Maybe there is one, but it got lost in all the action. SCORE: [b]3.[/b][/color][/font][/size]
 
 
 
[size=3][font=Times New Roman][color=#000000][u]Final Score (out of 60):[b] 14[/b][/u] [/color][/font][/size]

This is the single best game of all time. If Gaben, Dale, Jesus, Calvin of Calvin and Hobbs, and Nicolas Cage collaborated on a game it was pale to the sheer mastery that is Battletoads. I am going through Battletoad withdraw even now, 43This is the single best game of all time. If Gaben, Dale, Jesus, Calvin of Calvin and Hobbs, and Nicolas Cage collaborated on a game it was pale to the sheer mastery that is Battletoads. I am going through Battletoad withdraw even now, 43 words into this review. Imagine the best feeling in the world. That is slave labor in a North Korean (best Korea) lumber camp, forced to work long hours at the threat of your young child's life relative to the level of euphoria realized by even the settings menu of this piece of art. I didn't think it was possible to capture the magnificence of the original Battletoads and condense it to my phone, but it happened. The graphics are just as stunning as the original NES game, the controls just as tight. The characters are endearing and the humor adds to the fantastic story. The gameplay is fast-paced yet wearisome it was not; I had to resort to less than "traditional" methods in order for my feeble mind to respond to the stimulus Battletoads has to offer; my neighbor "Dope" Dan and I became quite close acquaintances, or would have if it weren't for the draw of the game. This game is without fault, bar none, save for the fact that it is not endless, however the replay value and incredible story depth, as well as subtle references drew me in for playthrough after playthrough. I could easily log hundreds of hours if it weren't for my pesky human body not being able to handle the incredible volume of dopamine coursing through my mortal veins and its inability to function great lengths of time without nourishment and intestinal relief, although the latter difficulty is easily solved by a trip to Walgreen's for a 24 pack of adult diapers, unfortunately I depleted their stock before long. All in all, this game is better than going out for mint chocolate chip ice cream with Jesus, the guy from the Dos Equis commercials, and Olivia Wilde while riding a Charizard. In fact, comparing Battletoads to such a scenario is ridiculous, as is any comparison, because this level of quality is in a class of its own. All else is trash's trash, regurgitated by Satan and Hitler. Anyone who has ever enjoyed anything absolutely must pick up Battletoads. Just be sure you have enough adult diapers. Collapse

rt_summary: Toddlers use their special abilities to stop a media mogul (Jon Voight) from altering the minds of children.
meta_summary: The adventure continues with a new generation of talking toddlers.   This time, the baby geniuses find themselves at the center of a nefarious scheme led by powerful media mogul Bill Biscane (Voight) to use his state-of-the-art satellite system to control the minds of the world's population.  (Sony)
